awd_titl_txt: EAGER: SaTC: Early-Stage Interdisciplinary Collaboration: Econometrically Inferring and Using Individual Privacy Preferences
awd_abstract_narration:
Many online platforms use economic mechanisms to estimate the best ways to match consumers and businesses with products and services. Effective matches may require using personal consumer data but doing so may intrude on consumers' privacy.  This project will use formal concepts of privacy to analyze the use of personal information in mechanism design. The goal is to develop tools for understanding the value and cost of collecting and using personal data, and provide mechanisms that allow designers to build systems that make meaningful and well understood tradeoffs between utility and privacy.

The project combines research on mechanism design and econometrics to provide a new perspective on privacy. The project will develop methods that use ideas from econometrics to reveal concrete privacy preferences for individuals and aggregate distributions, and connect those preferences to formal privacy models, including differential privacy. The revealed privacy preferences for individuals, or aggregate for distributions, can then be used to design mechanisms with concrete and meaningful privacy and utility tradeoffs based on users' individual privacy preferences. The broader goal is to transform abstract privacy guarantees into concrete tools for incorporating privacy preferences to maximize consumer utility as well as business decisions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The main goal of this project is to close the gap between privacy theory as well as mechanisms that implement privacy concepts that have been developed by the computer science community, and human perception of privacy informing their behavior. In this project we were able to measure the impact of the individual perception of privacy on behavior in non-experimental settings by exploiting a unique mechanism incentivizing users on Yelp, an online platform publishing business-specific consumer reviews. Yelp annually promotes a small share of its users to elite status. Those users are rewarded with the access to special events as well as free or discounted food and merchandise, and their reviews are boosted in rankings relative to other reviews. In return,  they are required to provide and verify certain personal identifiers, which become publicly observable. As a result, other users can more easily scrutinize their personal details and learn the business establishments they frequent from their reviews. 

  

We coin the term ?tabooness?  and define it as a measure of isolation of a given review among other reviews for the same business normalized for a given business category. The fewer reviews a given business has relative to other businesses in the same category, the easier it is to single out a review by a given user. This, in turn, facilitates identification of specific shopping behavior of this user or even their location. Yelp business categories vary by the level of tabooness they may seem for reviewers. By one of our measures, Health & Medical provides the highest level of tabooness, almost five times more than Arts & Entertainment or three times more than Restaurants, both of which are among the least taboo categories. Intuitively, it is reasonable to expect Yelp users to be less comfortable revealing their attendance of a medical establishment than they would be about a typical restaurant. We measure how a promotion of a given user to the elite category changes that user's reviewing prevalence for businesses that differ in their respective measures of tabooness.

 Our results indicate that although elite users post more reviews on average than non-elite users, their reviewing activity shifts to business categories with lower tabooness. The promotion of a user to the elite status increases their reviewing of Restaurants by almost 6 times more and of Arts & Entertainment establishments by almost 7 times more than that of the businesses in the Health & Medical category. Our results have broader implications for companies and government agencies which rely on voluntarily provided user data.


Last Modified: 10/09/2023
Modified by: Denis Nekipelov
